metadata.title: apcamargo/genomad: geNomad v1.11.0
metadata.description:
Added

  • Add the --lenient-taxonomy and --full-ictv-lineage options to the annotate, find-proviruses, and end-to-end modules. The --lenient-taxonomy option enables assignment of genomes to taxa below the family rank (subfamily, genus, subgenus, and species). The --full-ictv-lineage option enables the output of the full ICTV lineage of each genome, including ranks that are hidden by default (subrealm, subkingdom, subphylum, subclass, suborder, subfamily, and subgenus).

Changed

  • Remove the --conservative-taxonomy option of the annotate and end-to-end modules.

metadata.title: geNomad database
metadata.description:
Marker database used by geNomad for virus and plasmid identification.

  • genomad_db_v1.9.tar.gz: MMseqs2 profile database. Entries are decorated with taxonomy information from a custom taxdump based on ICTV's MSL39.
  • genomad_hmm_v1.9.tar.gz: HMMER HMM models.
  • genomad_metadata_v1.9.tsv.gz: Metadata for all the 227,918 markers.
  • genomad_msa_v1.9.tar.gz: Multiple sequence alignments in FASTA format.

metadata.title: Cameroonian blackflies (Diptera: Simuliidae) harbour a plethora of (RNA) viruses
metadata.description:
Fasta file (blackfly_viral_genomes.fasta) with identified virus sequences in Cameroonian blackflies and a corresponding table with their taxonomy when possible (taxonomy_data.tsv). Viruses were identified with geNomad v1.7.0 and Diamond blastx v2.0.11 with the NCBI nr database (accessed 23-03-2023).

We also included a fata file with all assembled sequences across all blackfly samples (blackfly.all.fasta)

data.title: Cameroonian blackflies (Diptera: Simuliidae) harbour a plethora of (RNA) viruses

metadata.title: Viral catalogue from faecal microbiomes of great tits and blue tits
metadata.description:
Overview:

The vertebrate gut microbiome plays crucial roles in host health and disease. However, there is limited data on the microbiomes of wild birds, most of which is restricted to barcode sequences. We therefore explored the use of shotgun metagenomics on the faecal microbiomes of two wild bird species widely used as model organisms in ecological studies: the great tit (Parus major) and the Eurasian blue tit (Cyanistes caeruleus). High and Medium quality Metagenome Assembled Genomes (MAGs) were assembled from these metagenomes and are made available as a catalogue in this archive.

Methods:

Metagenomic reads were trimmed, and quality controlled using FastP configured to a minimum phred score of 20 and minimum length of 50 bp. The potential viral and plasmidic sequences were retrieved from the assembled contigs using GeNomad v1.8.0 (Camargo et al. 2023) and the quality of these viral sequences was then assessed using CheckV v 1.0.3 (Nayfach et al. 2021) using the checkV database v 1.5. Putative viral sequences longer than 1000bp carrying at least one hallmark viral gene or no detectable cellular genes were considered in this analysis. The viral sequences were clustered into species-level vOTU clusters using mmseqs2 v2.13 using an identity threshold of 95% over 75% of the longest sequence. For viral species identified as Caudoviral, the potential host was inferred using iPhop v1.3.3 (Roux et al 2023).

Files:

  • The vOTU_characteristics.csv table contains the sequence characteristics from CheckV and the viral taxonomy determined by GeNomad
  • The vOTU_PredictedHost.csv table contains the viral sequence inferred host from iPhop
  • The vOTU_representatives.fasta file contains the fasta sequence of the vOTU representatives

data.title: Viral catalogue from faecal microbiomes of great tits and blue tits

metadata.title: Virus Specific Markers
metadata.description:
CC by 4.0, Antonio Camargo, I am only redistributing part of the amazing work by A. Camargo and others, as described in their publication:

Camargo, A. P., Roux, S., Schulz, F., Babinski, M., Xu, Y., Hu, B., Chain, P. S. G., Nayfach, S., & Kyrpides, N. C. — Nature Biotechnology (2023), DOI: 10.1038/s41587-023-01953-y.

 

--

This is the virus specific markers data set, the fraction of markers that are labeled as being at least specific for viruses, therefore labeled as `*V' or `V*' in the MMSeqs2 profile database file `genomad db v1.7.tar.gz' from https://zenodo.org/records/10594875, CC by 4.0, Antonio Camargo.
MMseqs2 Version: 15.6f452 was used to generate the database using the subcommand `createdb'.

metadata.title: geNomad minimal test data
metadata.description: Very small reference database for geNomad derived from version 1.7 as described here https://github.com/apcamargo/genomad/issues/104

metadata.title: Data supporting "Transformer Model Generated Bacteriophage Genomes are Compositionally Distinct from Natural Sequences"
metadata.description:
Sequence and composition data supporting doi: 10.1101/2024.03.19.585716. Uncompressed file size is ~5.8GB.

Data in zip files is organized by sequence provenance (generRNA, natural, or transformer (megaDNA)). Common file types between folders include:

  • Multi-record fasta file: Sequence data for all sequences of a given provenance. For generRNA sequences, these are found within the `seq` column of file "MFE_distribution_Fig4a.csv"
  • Composition files: Individual sequence level compositional metrics for sliding 120 bp windows. Only structural metrics were used in this study.
  • Genomad: Results from the genomad pipeline (https://portal.nersc.gov/genomad/)
  • Stats: Aggregate statistics for all sequences of a given provenance.

The natural folder also has a metadata file detailing the taxonomy for all natural sequences.

Figure datasets are the cleaned (sometimes aggregated) datasets that underly specific figures in the manuscript. The figure designations are based on the order in: https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2024.03.19.585716v1.

data.title: Data supporting "Transformer Model Generated Bacteriophage Genomes are Compositionally Distinct from Natural Sequences"

metadata.title: GeNomad_virus__gene_annotations
metadata.description: Gene annotations are provided for the 881,295 contigs (no size cutoff) that GeNomad determined were viral. See publication: Population ecology and biogeochemical implications of ssDNA and dsDNA viruses along a permafrost thaw gradient.

metadata.title: Additional data and code for "You can move, but you can't hide: identification of mobile genetic elements with geNomad"
metadata.description:
• benchmark_data: Data used to train and evaluate the classification models.
  • giant_virus_data: Sequences and metadata of giant viruses identified in public metagenomes.
  • neural_network_training: Code used to train geNomad's neural network-based classification model.
  • provirus_data: Data used to train and evaluate the conditional random field model employed by geNomad to identify provirus regions.
  • reference_sequences: Sequences of chromosomes, plasmids, and viruses that were used to build geNomad's marker dataset and to generate the training data for the classification models.

creators.name: Camargo, Antonio
creators.affiliation: DOE Joint Genome Institute, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, USA

data.title: Additional data and code for "You can move, but you can't hide: identification of mobile genetic elements with geNomad"
